articles.headline: Negotiations on Trans-Pacific Trade Pact Are Extended, Fueling Hope
articles.snippet: Trade ministers for 12 Pacific Rim nations extended talks into Saturday on the Trans-Pacific Partnership, hoping that that they were close enough to complete a deal.
articles.abstract: Trade ministers for 12 Pacific Rim nations extended talks into Saturday on the Trans-Pacific Partnership, hoping that that they were close enough to complete a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Trade ministers for 12 Pacific Rim nations, including the United States and Japan, on Friday neared agreement on an array of differences covering automotive, pharmaceutical and dairy exports, and decided to extend the negotiations into Saturday in hope of concluding the biggest regional pact in history.

articles.headline: Automakers Ask Europe for Leniency in Emissions Testing
articles.snippet: Under the new plan, cars in Europe would for the first time be tested on the road, using portable equipment, instead of in laboratories.
articles.abstract: Under the new plan, cars in Europe would for the first time be tested on the road, using portable equipment, instead of in laboratories.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despite the cloud cast by the Volkswagen scandal, automakers are proposing that they be allowed a 70 percent increase in the nitrogen oxides their cars emit, unreleased documents show, as part of new European pollution tests.

articles.headline: A Snapshot of Students Lost: Young and Old, but All Striving
articles.snippet: An instructor and eight students from various walks of life and ages were remembered as an Oregon community tried to come to grips with a mass shooting.
articles.abstract: An instructor and eight students from various walks of life and ages were remembered as an Oregon community tried to come to grips with a mass shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEBURG, Ore. — The instructor was a gray-bearded, pipe-smoking fisherman who honed his love of literature through years of writing about chasing summer steelheads. His students were the face of community colleges across America — a mix of young and old, some on the path to bright careers, some returning after decades of wrong turns. All had just begun a class on the art of constructing a reasoned argument when suddenly, the incomprehensible literally burst through the door.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller, Dave Philipps and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Cable and Satellite Ads Aim to Revamp the Industry’s Image
articles.snippet: Companies are looking to win over frustrated customers with new marketing campaigns that make fun of the industry’s lousy reputation.
articles.abstract: Companies are looking to win over frustrated customers with new marketing campaigns that make fun of the industry’s lousy reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who knew cable guys had a sense of humor?

articles.headline: Airstrike Hits Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The U.S. military said “there may have been collateral damage” to a medical facility in Kunduz. Doctors Without Borders said 19 were killed and dozens wounded.
articles.abstract: The U.S. military said “there may have been collateral damage” to a medical facility in Kunduz. Doctors Without Borders said 19 were killed and dozens wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A crowded hospital in the embattled city of Kunduz that treats war wounded came under attack on Saturday and the American military acknowledged that it may have killed 19 patients, staff members and others at the facility while firing on insurgents nearby.

articles.headline: Deaths Draw Attention to Wall Street’s Grueling Pace
articles.snippet: The deaths of young bankers have raised concern about jobs known for long hours and heavy workloads and how they affect the junior workers who do them.
articles.abstract: The deaths of young bankers have raised concern about jobs known for long hours and heavy workloads and how they affect the junior workers who do them.
articles.lead_paragraph: In retrospect, it was around Easter that John Hughes began to think something unusual was going on with his middle son, Thomas, a 29-year-old investment banker.

articles.headline: Confusion, Horror and Heroism in Oregon Shooting
articles.snippet: In classrooms adjacent to a shooting, students crawled into hiding, fled for their lives or helped the wounded.
articles.abstract: In classrooms adjacent to a shooting, students crawled into hiding, fled for their lives or helped the wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEBURG, Ore. — Twenty-year-old Marc Beckwith was in Room 16 of low-slung, mansard-roofed Snyder Hall, preparing for his computer lab. Cassandra Welding, also 20, was slipping into the lab room just as a familiar figure was slipping out.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller, Michael Wines and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Mass Murderers Fit Profile, as Do Many Others Who Don’t Kill
articles.snippet: What seems telling about these killers is not how much they have in common, but how much they look and seem like so many who don’t inflict harm.
articles.abstract: What seems telling about these killers is not how much they have in common, but how much they look and seem like so many who don’t inflict harm.
articles.lead_paragraph: They have become one of the most notorious and alarming stripes of evil. People who, when you think back, seemed off. Didn’t dress right. Kept to themselves. Were nursing a bitterness that smoldered inside of them.
articles.byline: By N. R. Kleinfield, Russ Buettner, David W. Chen and Nikita Stewart

articles.headline: Billions From U.S. Fail to Sustain Foreign Forces
articles.snippet: Numerous American-trained security forces overseas have collapsed, stalled or defected, calling into question a central tenet of President Obama’s approach to combating insurgencies.
articles.abstract: Numerous American-trained security forces overseas have collapsed, stalled or defected, calling into question a central tenet of President Obama’s approach to combating insurgencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With alarming frequency in recent years, thousands of American-trained security forces in the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia have collapsed, stalled or defected, calling into question the effectiveness of the tens of billions of dollars spent by the United States on foreign military training programs, as well as a central tenet of the Obama administration’s approach to combating insurgencies.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Tim Arango

articles.headline: In Putin’s Syria Intervention, Fear of a Weak Government Hand
articles.snippet: The specter of mass protest seems to have haunted President Vladimir V. Putin throughout his political life, and that fear informs Russia’s forceful intervention in Syria.
articles.abstract: The specter of mass protest seems to have haunted President Vladimir V. Putin throughout his political life, and that fear informs Russia’s forceful intervention in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the night of Dec. 5, 1989, Vladimir V. Putin, then a lieutenant colonel in the K.G.B., watched with alarm as thousands of East Germans in Dresden swarmed the riverside compound of the dreaded secret police, the Stasi.

articles.headline: Valeant’s Drug Price Strategy Enriches It, but Infuriates Patients and Lawmakers
articles.snippet: A pharmaceutical company buys old drugs and increases the price multifold, a profitable business model that is drawing anger and making the traditional drug industry nervous.
articles.abstract: A pharmaceutical company buys old drugs and increases the price multifold, a profitable business model that is drawing anger and making the traditional drug industry nervous.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Michael Pearson has become a billionaire from his tough tactics as the head of the fast-growing Valeant Pharmaceuticals International.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Volkswagen Engine-Rigging Scheme Said to Have Begun in 2008
articles.snippet: The carmaker installed emissions-cheating software in 2008 after realizing that a new diesel motor could not meet pollution standards, people familiar with an internal inquiry said.
articles.abstract: The carmaker installed emissions-cheating software in 2008 after realizing that a new diesel motor could not meet pollution standards, people familiar with an internal inquiry said.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen began installing software devised to cheat on emissions tests in 2008 after realizing that a new diesel engine, developed at great expense, could not meet pollution standards in the United States and other countries, people with knowledge of the automaker’s internal inquiry said on Sunday.

articles.headline: Doctors Without Borders Says It Is Leaving Kunduz After Strike on Hospital
articles.snippet: The aid organization also raised the death toll in Saturday’s airstrike, saying that three more patients had died, raising the total fatalities to 22 — 10 patients and 12 staff members.
articles.abstract: The aid organization also raised the death toll in Saturday’s airstrike, saying that three more patients had died, raising the total fatalities to 22 — 10 patients and 12 staff members.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The situation in the war-torn Afghan city of Kunduz became more precarious for residents caught between government troops and Taliban militants after the withdrawal Sunday of an aid group that was one of the last providers of medical services there.

articles.headline: At 80, Yankee Magazine Is Thriving as an Avatar of New England
articles.snippet: The publication, which has chronicled the Yankee spirit since 1935, has managed to stay profitable and even grow despite the decline in print media.
articles.abstract: The publication, which has chronicled the Yankee spirit since 1935, has managed to stay profitable and even grow despite the decline in print media.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, N.H. — The beginning of fall was just two days away and the staff of Yankee magazine had a situation on its hands: The leaves were still green.

articles.headline: A Conundrum for Jeb Bush: How to Use George W.
articles.snippet: The 43rd president is among the most popular figures among Republican voters, but bringing him on the campaign trail could undermine his younger brother’s prospects in a general election.
articles.abstract: The 43rd president is among the most popular figures among Republican voters, but bringing him on the campaign trail could undermine his younger brother’s prospects in a general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — With Jeb Bush struggling to connect with some Republican activists, his campaign has begun exploring whether to bring in the person it thinks may be best equipped to give him a boost with skeptical conservatives: his brother George W. Bush.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Taliban’s New Leader Strengthens His Hold With Intrigue and Battlefield Victory
articles.snippet: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour has become central to the Taliban’s revival as a powerful insurgency that poses a grave threat to the Afghan government.
articles.abstract: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour has become central to the Taliban’s revival as a powerful insurgency that poses a grave threat to the Afghan government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — If ever there was a Taliban bureaucrat who seemed set on a less than stellar career path, it was Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour.

articles.headline: Politicians Turn to Start-Ups for Grasp of ‘Gig Economy’
articles.snippet: Policy makers are turning to tech leaders and start-up executives to better understand the future of work and its implications for workers.
articles.abstract: Policy makers are turning to tech leaders and start-up executives to better understand the future of work and its implications for workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marco Zappacosta runs an Internet start-up called Thumbtack that matches plumbers, yoga instructors and other workers with jobs, putting him in the middle of what is called the “gig economy.” Now, that position has made him in demand with a group of political power players.

articles.headline: Dollar’s Surge Against Other Currencies Weighs Down United States’ Economy
articles.snippet: Among other effects, the dollar’s strength is expected to push into next year any move by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
articles.abstract: Among other effects, the dollar’s strength is expected to push into next year any move by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the American dollar began to surge against foreign currencies late last year, economists have warned that the repercussions would eventually be felt on the home front.

articles.headline: Policy Makers Skeptical on Preventing Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: A Federal Reserve conference highlighted the challenge of heading off events like the 2008 crisis, since they are hard to anticipate.
articles.abstract: A Federal Reserve conference highlighted the challenge of heading off events like the 2008 crisis, since they are hard to anticipate.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The 2008 financial crisis convinced most people in the world of central banking that it would be a good idea to try to prevent that kind of thing from happening again.

articles.headline: U.S. Aims to Put More Pressure on ISIS in Syria
articles.snippet: About 3,000 to 5,000 Arab fighters are to join more than 20,000 Kurdish combatants in an offensive backed by dozens of allied warplanes to pressure Raqqa, the Islamic State’s main stronghold in Syria.
articles.abstract: About 3,000 to 5,000 Arab fighters are to join more than 20,000 Kurdish combatants in an offensive backed by dozens of allied warplanes to pressure Raqqa, the Islamic State’s main stronghold in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American-led coalition fighting the Islamic State has begun preparing to open a major front in northeastern Syria, aiming to put pressure on Raqqa, the terrorist group’s de facto capital, according to military and administration officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Delegating, Jack Dorsey Will Lead Twitter and Square
articles.snippet: Mr. Dorsey has been aggressively making changes as interim chief since Dick Costolo stepped down on July 1.
articles.abstract: Mr. Dorsey has been aggressively making changes as interim chief since Dick Costolo stepped down on July 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Shortly after Twitter’s board of directors began its search for a new chief executive in June, it said it would only accept someone willing to commit to the job full time. It was a not-so-subtle message to Twitter’s co-founder and interim boss, Jack Dorsey, that he would have to give up his job running Square, a mobile payments start-up, if he wanted to run Twitter on a permanent basis.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Trans-Pacific Partnership Is Reached, but Faces Scrutiny in Congress
articles.snippet: Securing approval from Congress for the deal between the United States and 11 Pacific Rim nations could be the toughest fight President Obama faces in his final year in office.
articles.abstract: Securing approval from Congress for the deal between the United States and 11 Pacific Rim nations could be the toughest fight President Obama faces in his final year in office.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The United States, Japan and 10 other Pacific Rim nations on Monday reached final agreement on the largest regional trade accord in history, teeing up what could be the toughest fight President Obama will face in his final year in office: securing approval from Congress.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Denies Request to Hear Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: The Justice Department had asked the court to review an appeals court decision, saying the ruling made it harder to prosecute insider trading.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department had asked the court to review an appeals court decision, saying the ruling made it harder to prosecute insider trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to review an appeals court decision that made it harder to prosecute insider trading and threatens to undermine a number of convictions.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: El Faro, Missing Ship, Has No Sign of Survivors
articles.snippet: No survivors have been found from the U.S. cargo ship El Faro, which went missing near the Bahamas during Hurricane Joaquin.
articles.abstract: No survivors have been found from the U.S. cargo ship El Faro, which went missing near the Bahamas during Hurricane Joaquin.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — By the time the cargo ship El Faro pulled out of the busy port in Jacksonville, Fla., last Tuesday ready to begin its routine 1,200-mile run of goods to San Juan, P.R., Tropical Storm Joaquin, as it had been recently christened, was threatening to become a hurricane.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez, Richard Pérez-Peña and Frances Robles
